Using Prawn in Rails 3

These instructions are a modified version of Using prawn in rails and they don't work yet.

Using Bundler

Add prawn to your Gemfile:

gem 'prawn'

Install:

$ bundle install

Create a file called config/initializers/prawn.rb and in it, add one of the following lines, depending on your Prawn version:

Prawn through 0.8.4: 

require "prawn/core"

Prawn 0.9+ or git: 

require "prawn"

Now, Prawn should be ready to go.

Basic test

# config.routes.rb

  resources :widgets, only: [:index]

# app/controllers/widgets_controller.rb
class WidgetsController < ApplicationController
  class TestDocument < Prawn::Document
    def to_pdf
      text "Hello World!"
      render
    end
  end

  def index
    output = TestDocument.new.to_pdf
    respond_to do |format|
      format.pdf { 
        send_data output, :filename => "hello.pdf", :type => "application/pdf", :disposition => "inline"
      }
      format.html {
        render :text => "<h1>Use .pdf</h1>".html_safe
      }
    end
  end
end

Start your rails app and go to http://localhost:4000/widgets

You should see an HTML message to "Use .pdf". Now try http://localhost:4000/widgets

You should see a PDF rendered inline with "Hello World!" in it.

Adding Prawn Extensions

You might also want to make use of prawn-layout or prawn-security. If you are running Prawn <= 0.8.4, these are separate libraries. (For Prawn 0.9+ or git master, this section is irrelevant, as these libraries have been moved into core Prawn.)

The process for requiring these external libraries is essentially the same as for Prawn itself, so we trust you to be able to figure it out. Here's a quick recap of the process:

  • Use git submodule add ... to pull down the extension you want
  • Lock the downloaded submodule to the stable branch if you aren't sure what else to do.
  • Update submodules (optional for prawn-layout and prawn-security, only helps with running tests and examples)
  • Add extension's lib/ folder to your load_paths in config/environment.rb
  • Add requires as needed to config/initializers/prawn.rb

Additional Rails Configuration

By this point, you have Prawn downloaded and Rails is loading it and any necessary extensions. All that remains to be done is a little housekeeping so that your application can actually locate and render your PDF reports.

We like to keep our reports in with the rest of our application, so we create a folder called app/reports:

$ mkdir app/reports

To preserve Rails autoloading support, we add this new folder to the load_paths in config/environment.rb:

config.load_paths << "#{RAILS_ROOT}/app/reports"

We're almost done. All that's left to do is to register a mime type in config/initializers/mime_types.rb so that respond_to will work correctly in our controllers.

Mime::Type.register_alias "application/pdf", :pdf

Now everything should be all set, so let's give it a quick test.

Rendering PDFs

Suppose we have the following code in app/reports/hello_report.rb:

class HelloReport < Prawn::Document
  def to_pdf
    text "Hello world"
    render
  end
end

Rendering this report from a controller is easy!

class HelloController < ApplicationController
   def index
    output = HelloReport.new.to_pdf

    respond_to do |format|
      format.pdf do
        send_data output, :filename => "hello.pdf", 
                          :type => "application/pdf"
      end
    end
  end
end

If all goes well, you should be able to fire up your browser and download the PDF generated by this action. While it won't be the most exciting report in the world, you'll be ready at this point to move on to creating your own beautiful PDFs with Prawn+Rails.

What If Prawn Still Isn't Working?

If you have trouble following the instructions in this guide, you may want to read the relevant git / Rails documentation before asking Prawn developers for help. The process described above could be used for vendoring pretty much any ruby library, and we've provided this guide only because the question comes up often. Since Prawn is at a very young age, we much prefer to spend our time focusing on its development rather than on how to integrate it with other Ruby projects (including Rails).

That said, if you get stuck and can't find better help elsewhere, feel free to contact us on the "Prawn mailing list":http://groups.google.com/group/prawn-ruby

Acknowledgements

This guide, while based on the workflow of the core Prawn developers, was inspired by and is indeed quite similar to a "great article":http://kangaroobox.blogspot.com/2009/07/generating-pdfs-in-rails-using-prawn.html by Richard Hurt. You might want to check that out for a few extra ideas.
